Description: Rim sherd of Attic or South Ionian pottery cup with concave everted rim; traces of handle attachment; very worn; probably wholly glazed; inscription on exterior.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B3 (possibly)
Curator's comments: Schlotzhauer identifies the sherd as coming from a Type 9C South Ionian cup with everted rim. Type 9C cups correspond to Attic Siana or Gordion cups and find parallels with Hayes' Ionian Cup Type X (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) and Vallet and Villard's Ionian Cup type B3 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88) The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. Type 5 cups are rare at Naukratis whereas there are numerous examples of Type 9 cups. Both types were common drinking vessels found in Greeks sanctuaries, including the sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus. However, the shape of the lip on this sherd is distinctly different from that from other Type 9C cups, for example British Museum 1888,0601.255.
The concavity of the rim points rather to Attica, although the clay, even if it is washed out, is pale for Attic.
Bibliographic references: Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 716, no. 740)
Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 52, no. 264)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.722) (Phase 3)
